original_result.user_prompt:
Restricted Stock Units
Why Do Companies Grant RSUs?
Startup and early-stage companies need to bring in employees, contractors, and other workers to build their operations before sustained revenue is available to pay competitive salaries. Some of the money necessary to build talent teams may come from investors or venture capital, but it is common to supplement that with a stock incentive as well. A promise of stock is also helpful in attracting talent away from other jobs and compensating employees for the risks inherent in working for startups that may not necessarily survive.

How Do RSUs Work?
RSUs can come with various restrictions. Some are subject to only a vesting schedule and may be referred to as ‘single-trigger’ RSUs. A vesting schedule might, for example, be a three-year arrangement that issues a specified number of shares upon the completion of a certain period of service. An employee who leaves the company prior to a vesting date forfeits the portion of their share allocation that is unvested.

Other RSUs, called ‘double-trigger’, may include additional conditions that must be fulfilled. An additional requirement might be that the employee successfully completes a certain work assignment such as developing a new product or writing a software program, in order to receive shares.

Additional restrictions might have other performance requirements or limits on the sale or transfer of the stock. The RSU contract may also dictate whether the employee gets actual stock or the cash equivalent.

83(b) Elections
Filing an 83(b) election with the IRS allows the recipient of Restricted Stock to pay income tax on the shares when granted rather than when received. An 83(b) election, which must be filed within 30 days of the initial grant, will bring on the income tax liability much sooner, but it will also generally mean that the tax burden is lower since the value of the stock at the time of grant will likely be lower than it will be at the time it is later received.

Importantly, however, an 83(b) election is not available for RSUs, which are taxed under a different part of the tax code.


--------

<[client.hooli-schwab.com](https://client.hooli-schwab.com)>
original_result.completion_text:
<[client.hooli-schwab.com](https://client.hooli-schwab.com)>

Why do companies issue Restricted Stock Units (RSUs)? To attract and retain talent, especially in startup and early-stage companies where funds for competitive salaries are limited. RSUs act as a form of stock incentive to motivate employees and compensate them for the risks involved in joining startups.

How do RSUs work? RSUs can be categorized into two types - single-trigger and double-trigger. Single-trigger RSUs vests after a predetermined period of service, whereas double-trigger RSUs require both a set period of service and the fulfillment of additional conditions, such as achieving specific milestones. Additional restrictions may apply regarding performance targets, stock sale limitations, and whether the employee receives actual stock or its cash equivalent.

What is an 83(b) election? It's a provision allowing the recipient of RSUs to declare income tax on the shares at the time of grant rather than when they are received. However, this option is not applicable for RSUs. Here are some real-world examples illustrating the usage of RSUs in corporate settings:

1. Tech Startup Scenario:
Company XYZ, a tech startup, offers restricted stock units (RSUs) to its employees as part of their compensation package. The goal is to attract talented engineers and developers who would typically command higher salaries in larger, established tech firms. By offering RSUs, Company XYZ hopes to secure top talent and encourage long-term commitment among its staff members.

In this scenario, an engineer named John joins Company XYZ and signs up for an RSU plan that includes both single-trigger and double-trigger vesting schedules. He agrees to stay with the company for five years and complete a challenging project involving artificial intelligence technology development. If he meets these criteria, his RSUs will vest, giving him ownership stakes in the company without requiring immediate monetary expenditure.

2. Venture Capital Funding:
A biotechnology startup, ABC Corp., has recently secured $5 million in venture capital funding to develop a groundbreaking cancer drug. As part of

RSUs operate through single-trigger or double-trigger vesting schedules, imposing further conditions like project completions or sales restrictions

Example 2:

RSUs serve as a form of equity compensation used by startup and early-stage companies to attract and retain employees while building their operations. They offer a potential financial benefit tied to the success and longe[l]vity of the company.

        Restricted Stock Units
Why Do Companies Grant RSUs?
Startup and early-stage companies need to bring in employees, contractors, and other workers to build their operations before sustained revenue is available to pay competitive salaries. A vesting schedule might, for example, be a three-year arrangement that issues a specified number of shares upon the completion of a certain period of service. An employee who leaves the company prior to a vesting date forfeits the portion of their share allocation that is unvested.

Other RSUs, called ‘double-trigger’, may include additional conditions that must be fulfilled. An additional requirement might be that the employee successfully completes a certain work assignment such as developing a new product or writing a software program, in order to receive shares.

Additional restrictions might have other performance requirements or limits on the sale or transfer of the stock. The RSU contract may also dictate whether the employee gets actual stock or the cash equivalent.

Filing an 83(b) election with the IRS allows the recipient of Restricted Stock to pay income tax on the shares when granted rather than when received. guidelines_result.user_prompt:
Restricted Stock Units
Why Do Companies Grant RSUs?
Startup and early-stage companies need to bring in employees, contractors, and other workers to build their operations before sustained revenue is available to pay competitive salaries. Some of the money necessary to build talent teams may come from investors or venture capital, but it is common to supplement that with a stock incentive as well. A promise of stock is also helpful in attracting talent away from other jobs and compensating employees for the risks inherent in working for startups that may not necessarily survive.

How Do RSUs Work?
RSUs can come with various restrictions. Some are subject to only a vesting schedule and may be referred to as ‘single-trigger’ RSUs. A vesting schedule might, for example, be a three-year arrangement that issues a specified number of shares upon the completion of a certain period of service. An employee who leaves the company prior to a vesting date forfeits the portion of their share allocation that is unvested.

Other RSUs, called ‘double-trigger’, may include additional conditions that must be fulfilled. An additional requirement might be that the employee successfully completes a certain work assignment such as developing a new product or writing a software program, in order to receive shares.

Additional restrictions might have other performance requirements or limits on the sale or transfer of the stock. The RSU contract may also dictate whether the employee gets actual stock or the cash equivalent.

83(b) Elections
Filing an 83(b) election with the IRS allows the recipient of Restricted Stock to pay income tax on the shares when granted rather than when received. An 83(b) election, which must be filed within 30 days of the initial grant, will bring on the income tax liability much sooner, but it will also generally mean that the tax burden is lower since the value of the stock at the time of grant will likely be lower than it will be at the time it is later received.

Importantly, however, an 83(b) election is not available for RSUs, which are taxed under a different part of the tax code.

text_generation_completion_result.final_completion_text:
<[client.hooli-schwab.com](https://client.hooli-schwab.com)>

Why do companies issue Restricted Stock Units (RSUs)? To attract and retain talent, especially in startup and early-stage companies where funds for competitive salaries are limited. RSUs act as a form of stock incentive to motivate employees and compensate them for the risks involved in joining startups.

How do RSUs work? RSUs can be categorized into two types - single-trigger and double-trigger. Single-trigger RSUs vests after a predetermined period of service, whereas double-trigger RSUs require both a set period of service and the fulfillment of additional conditions, such as achieving specific milestones. Additional restrictions may apply regarding performance targets, stock sale limitations, and whether the employee receives actual stock or its cash equivalent.

What is an 83(b) election? It's a provision allowing the recipient of RSUs to declare income tax on the shares at the time of grant rather than when they are received. However, this option is not applicable for RSUs. Here are some real-world examples illustrating the usage of RSUs in corporate settings:

1. Tech Startup Scenario:
Company XYZ, a tech startup, offers restricted stock units (RSUs) to its employees as part of their compensation package. The goal is to attract talented engineers and developers who would typically command higher salaries in larger, established tech firms. By offering RSUs, Company XYZ hopes to secure top talent and encourage long-term commitment among its staff members.

In this scenario, an engineer named John joins Company XYZ and signs up for an RSU plan that includes both single-trigger and double-trigger vesting schedules. He agrees to stay with the company for five years and complete a challenging project involving artificial intelligence technology development. If he meets these criteria, his RSUs will vest, giving him ownership stakes in the company without requiring immediate monetary expenditure.

2. Venture Capital Funding:
A biotechnology startup, ABC Corp., has recently secured $5 million in venture capital funding to develop a groundbreaking cancer drug. As part of
